posts.name: Emre Alp Ünal
posts.cooked: I’m new at a Robotics group named Novatron #10202 , also ı’m in electric department but i really don’t know about electric on FRC . I want to know equipments, robot’s pieces and thinks about that. Do anyone where can i know such thinks. I’d be so appreciate if someone explains to me.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
Looking at how a complete system is wired is good, also docs.wpilib.org or following some of the vendor build guides like CTRE or REV offer depending on what equipment you physically have

This is a full robot build guide for REV hardware as well as the links to the rets of the docs. FRC Robot Basics Guide | ION BUILD SYSTEM

CTRE guides have V6 and V5 variants that both have alot of good info if you use any CTRE hardware at all it’s worth reading here.

Welcome to the Phoenix 6 documentation. Individuals looking for Phoenix 5 documentation may locate it here. The Phoenix 6 software framework allows you to control and configure your CTR Electronics...

DavidMasin:

A little bit less updated but still explains well - 4.0 Electronics :: FRC Zero

That’s on me. We lost alot of student power to keep working on this as much as we’d like. The original plan was to have a comprehensive electrical common components and pneumatic common components for FRC with pictures and text. Just a issue of not having  enough people power to split our efforts from the main team tasks.

Side note the repo for content is public so if people want to continue along or add stuff we missed (like Krakens, because they didn’t exist at the time we wrote it originally, and we don’t have any in house to learn from)

link_counts.title: FRC Robot Basics Guide | ION BUILD SYSTEM
FIRST Robotics Competition Control System — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
THIS isn’t a bad document with good definitions of many components. It is somewhat redundant with other excellent sources posted here and suffers the same as many documents on the Internet - outdated. Many “electrical bibles” are made but many are not updated after initial publication and are limited to the equipment that the team uses that wrote the document.

The FRC Game Manual can help and take a look at the Robot Inspection Checklist

posts.name: Nate
posts.cooked:
I am a student, in my 3rd year of FRC this year and I have been in control of our electrical team I have Learned a lot and I still have much to learn. I will just give a photo/link dump of stuff I get information from and general photos of the layouts and other things.

Here are a bunch of diagrams for electrical stuff.

CTR Electronics They have a lot of the electrical components (Motors, Sensors, Cables…) used in FRC .

FRC has stuff on electrical too. Some more diagrams. Videos and lists of electrical components used.

FRC a second link from FRC , this is a more detailed list of most of the electrical components and what they do. (Some of this stuff is not used very much anymore though)

Slideshow with another list of FRC electronics and mentions some tools needed.

This guide is good for how everything fits together and talks about what things are.

Also for CTR electronics the Pheonix 6 software and documentation is a good place to look but can be a bit more complicated. (We are still just getting into using it)

(Some of these things have been already mentioned in the thread but I will keep them here too)

There is so much more out there all around Chief Delphi and the internet in general. Also reaching out to local teams is a good place to get more information and a good way to start collaborating and getting to know your local teams.

link_counts.title: Introduction to FRC Robot Wiring — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation
Hardware Component Overview — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: FRC 2468 publishes a lot of their work and at the bottom of THIS page is a major section called Other Resources with two electrical and sensor documents. Same caution as before - you likely will have similar but different, more modern versions of the major pieces of equipment.

Something I want to also mention is get good at making reliable connections!   You dont want to lose a match because a critical motor got disconnected!

My team uses Anderson Powerpoles ( housings , contacts ), and when crimped well (and ziptied together), it can make for a very reliable connection, and an anderson has never once failed on us. As a plus, pairs can actually slide together, so you can have them as a little block that you can just slide in 1 motion. Keep in mind that you need to get a anderson crimper tool to make these.

WAGO ’s are also a popular option, and also dont require any tools apart from wire strippers. However, my team has had problems with them in the past loosening, so we stuck with andersons.

In all, spending time to make sure that your wiring doesn’t come apart is time well spent, and this is something that you should make sure that you are paying attention to.

link_counts.title: WAGO 221 Inline Splicing Connector - 12 AWG - 50 Pack - REV Robotics

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
EmerqldWither:

My team uses Anderson Powerpoles ( housings , contacts ), and when crimped well (and ziptied together), it can make for a very reliable connection

Ziptying is the key. Some of the knockoff brand ones tend to slip apart, especially over time with lots of connect/disconnects bending it apart. The holes (half circle cutouts on each single connector) are meant for these little clips to keep them tight and joined, but these can fall out of the robot inverts for some reason… Climbing/swinging can do some weird stuff. Or if the fit isn’t right off the bat, it’s basically useless. Zip ties the first time, all the time.

811xhQA9i-L 1992×1793 244 KB

811xhQA9i-L 1992×1793 244 KB

811xhQA9i-L 1992×1793 244 KB

posts.name: Tim Winters
posts.cooked:
kingc95:

but these can fall out of the robot inverts for some reason

These will not fall out simply from being turned upside down. In all of 2024 I don’t think I saw one of these pop out on its own. They’re almost tough to take out by hand

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: Could be brand differences then, I’ve had some be loose, whether it’s the hole or the clip itself not fitting just right. Ziptie is a good fix if it does happen
